ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about rye and how to conduct sensory ethnographies.

* the reliance of eastern european societies on rye
* anthropological and psychological impacts of food
Being able to write a sensory ethnography, and being exposed to various forms of readings and evidences.

I gained a deeper understanding of rye and learned its rise and fall in history. Trying out embodied practices and writing ethnographies taught me how to awaken my senses and how incorporate them into my learning experience. The course brought me a new perspective of looking at the world, and inspired me to envision everything not from a human-centered perspective but a plant-centered one. (Also learned some nice recipes about bread making and cookie making!)
Learned so much about rye, and more broadly about the relationship between grains & humans, especially about the rise of grains and civilization

I learnt more on a subject that was previously unfamiliar to me and I enjoyed it.I also got very valuable feedback on my essays and improved my writing skills I also learnt how to bake 19th-century bread and pastries

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The biggest strength of this course is the hands-on activities that allow you to gain experiential knowledge to aid in your understanding of the readings and better evaluate arguments. I don't think this course has any weaknesses (other than the unfortunate fact that it is only available as a summer class). The only thing I didn't like was that papers were due at 5PM on Sunday instead of midnight. If you are working at a job or internship throughout the week and are primarily writing the paper over the weekend it is a big time crunch.

loved the multi disciplinary aspects, professors all put in lots of effort + have a ton of excitement for the subject, video content is well produced and accessible (audio and visuals are actually coherent compared to other online courses) 

sometimes student participation was lacking but not much to control regarding that

Strengths - Professor Trumpler, Maria, and Jeremy always provided consistent feedback and relatively quick grading turnover. They also made the zoom learning environment very comfortable and collaborative.
The medium of learning is very diverse. But I feel that the course could have more content directly related to women.

Strengths are the active assignments that really make you engage with the topic. The teaching staff is also a huge strength, all three instructors together have a lot of expertise and able to offer a lot of help.
strengths- The course is very engaging and interesting and the instructors' enthusiasm and love for the subject is clear and infectious. the material is also very engaging

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you just think the class description sounds interesting, definitely take it! It is a very unique class (that will also give you a WR credit if needed) and is not stressful at all.
Yes, you will have fun. Make sure to go to essay conferences early
yes! if you love anthropology or other social sciences, dive into this world of a grain that is at the edges of humanity

Absolutely, I would wholeheartedly recommend this course to other students! It provided a dynamic and engaging experience through embodied practice, and the written assignments were both enjoyable and thought-provoking. I genuinely enjoyed this interdisciplinary class and believe it would greatly benefit any student who might be interested the combination of rye, writing, and women's studies.
Absolutely! I lived the interactive aspect of this course!
ABSOLUTELY! GREAT prof & great way to get a writing credit
Definitely! (one of the best and fun)classes I've taken at Yale

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: multi disciplinary aspect

New perspectives of thinking about the world.
Improvements in baking skills.
Better sensitivity to surroundings.
Enhancement in writing.
I will incorporate more rye products and whole grain foods into my diet( since the class is about rye after all) and spread the knowledge i obtained about it to others
